Fields.DialogueText: Theodor, you're a dream, you know that?
Are... are you trying to flirt with me, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: No, uh, I just meant that you seem to be daydreaming.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Ja. I guess I was a little preoccupied for a Moment.
Yeah, you wouldn't want that to happen during a battle.
Do you ever get distracted when you're supposed to be focusing on something, Kapitän?
Then you shouldn't hold me Vorträge about it, Kapitän!
So you know how it feels when your imagination gets the best of you.
Never? I guess some people are really that focused...
I just want you to remain focused during the times when it's important.
I will make sure that when we go into battle, we won't have any problems. I wouldn't be able to forgive myself if anything bad were to happen to the crew.
Then let's make sure we're fully prepared, Theodor.
Jawohl!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: I mean, if you have to ask...

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitän?
Never mind. Sorry, you seemed to have your head in the clouds - but I didn't mean to interrupt.
Uhm. I... uhm....
Relax, Theodor. I'm not going to pounce on you.
Is everything okay?
I don't love the look of the sea. This is just the time where the Nixen attack. When we're nauseated and weary.
They don't appear to be hit by the storms like we are.
Who knows how they really feel? Hey, maybe they're really just hiding their pain!
I really do admire your willingness to see the best in hideous murder ships, Theodor, but-
Wait. I think I see some Nixen out in the distance.

Fields.MenuText: I hope it gives them more pain to hide.
We wait for the storm to pass.

Fields.DialogueText: It's getting rougher and rougher. I hope they can swim, and I mean that in the nice way.
Kapitän, are you sure? I know we usually don't aim well with the bad weather.
I just hope it passes before they get to us!
We're going to be fine. Look how far away they are.
*BOOM*
Kapitän, that nearly hit us!
Well, it looks like we're battling, one way or another.
@BATTLE
I'm admittedly biased, but I tend to think that they're more of the wolf-dressed-like-grandmother school of hiding things.
Oh! I like the Rotkäppchen reference! Well done!
Thank you.
But is a little positivity so much to ask for?
I need your help, Theodor.
Great. Happy to assist. What do you need?

Fields.MenuText: I need you to map out where we've been over the course of the last battle.
I want to know where the Morganas are heading to next.
Let's find out if we need any more ammo or supplies.

Fields.DialogueText: We've traveled very far, Kapitän. It'd be hard to judge and move about.
It'd be easier to track the Nixen if we knew how they moved. Sadly, we're unable to find them.
Don't we have someone else who does that?
Good point, Theodor. I guess I could use you for more appropriate strategizing.
If it's not too much of a problem, I think I can help record our battles to accurately judge our performance.
If that's what you want to do, then by all means. It should help quite a bit in the long run.
Excellent! I'm going to get to work right away!
I really need to work harder on my small talk.
@BATTLE
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Theodor, how goes the report and surveying?
Kapitän! It's not time for that. We've only had a couple of battles!
You've only recorded a couple of battles formally - but we've been fighting these things for a long, long time now. You must've started with some insights you wanted to test.
Ja, but... well, recording our battle progress may have proven to be a bigger challenge than I thought.

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry, you can do it!

Fields.DialogueText: What's wrong is that I feel like this is just overwhelming, and I can't seem to ever focus on my work.
You're telling me! One look at all of our statistics and my head starts spinning.
Thanks for the encouragement, Kapitän. But saying something and doing something are different things.
Setting aside the metaphor while I try to figure it out... you just need to find a way to relax.
... I know! I'll write some fairy tales!
That's the ticket.
I have just the perfect idea planned, too!
Do you know "Das Rätsel?"
Remind me.
There's a witch who tries to poison a prince, but poisons his horse, which poisons a raven, which poisons twelve bandits.
Okay.
And I feel like I'm looking at a dead bandit and I don't know how to figure out it's the fault of a dead raven, never mind the dead horse!
If there's anything I can do to help...
Oh, you already have!
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Theodor?
Theodor!!!
EEK!
*CRASH*
Sorry! Sorry! How's your head?
Am I bleeding?
No, doesn't look like it. But maybe you should sit for a few minutes.
Well, so am I. Did you need me for something, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: First things first. Why were you so distracted? Anything wrong?
I just wanted to talk about your performance today.

Fields.DialogueText: I've just had so much on my mind that I zoned out when I was looking at that ocean.
I know, I was distracted. I promise that it won't happen again!
Well, you're not the only one who has been forgetful. I've been at fault as well.
Theodor. I know that look.
Well... I think I lost my Notizbuch. With all of my stories.
Again?
Ja.
*sigh*
Oh, I don't think I can get concussed or anything. Please don't worry about me.
Yeah, well, I *do* worry about you, and I'm not likely to stop. But I'm glad about the general absence of concussions.
I have a look?
You have several, and I'm very fond of most of them.
Oh.
This one, on the other hand... Did something bad happen?
How could you lose it again?
Well, I didn't exactly misplace it this time. Instead, the book went overboard.
How did that happen?
We were at battle, and someone called out for help with loading the cannons. I was holding my book, so I put it down on the deck, and....
I see.
You're not mad, are you?

Fields.MenuText: I'm mad at the universe, not you.
I just feel bad for you. I know how much work you put into that book.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, worst case scenario, it's just a book. I liked it, but at least it wasn't food, or anything valuable.
I think it's not really a big deal... except all of my little stories are gone. Oh well, live and learn!
Oh, in the end, it's not really important! Ha ha ha!
I guess you'll have to get a new one.
Ja, I guess. Hey, look out there, are the Nixen changing formation?
Blast it, you're right! Whatever they're up to, we must put an end to it!
@BATTLE
... You're going out of your mind, huh?
Ja. Very much so.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Hmm... The Nixen's Taktiken, do they seem different to you?
I think so. It's like they're moving in one direction, like they've received some sort of secret message.
Genau! What do you think that means, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: The Morganas are up to something.
I have no idea. We're back to making guesses about dead robbers and poisoned ravens, I guess.

Fields.DialogueText: They could be.
Those Nixen must be so desperate. It must be because we're beating them so much.
Ja. Well said.
For now, we have to be prepared for any surprises. The worst part about their movements is that we cannot predict them.
That's why I've been making Notizen after each battle. Soon we'll have enough information gathered to see what they're up to.
That's excellent. Keep up the good work, Theodor.
Jawohl!
Look, Kapitän, I got a new Notizbuch. Remember, the other one got destroyed?
Oh, I remember. Congratulations on the replacement, I guess?
*sigh* Ja. I really liked the last story I was working on. It was about the Nixen.
A fairy tale about the Morganas?
Well, they were all bats, but I think the metaphor is pretty obvious. I went halfway through the story, but never wrote the ending.

Fields.MenuText: Did you have an ending in mind?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja. It was going to have a happy ending for the two main characters.
Well, it was nice. I don't think it was my best story, though.
Danke! Maybe I will!
I hope we can make some time for you to write, Theodor. Things have been weird out here lately - even by our standards.
Ja, the Nixen are still acting so strangely. It's almost as if...
What's going on?
I'm just imagining things again. Forget about it!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
No, never mind.
You guess?
Honestly, I was hoping the old one would turn up somehow. I know how much work you put into it.
The changes in the Nixen's tactics have been abrupt. And odd.
Let me see the map. Ah, it's as if they just went about face and turned around!
Should we follow, or wait till they come back?
There happens to be an awful lot of them. I hope we can keep up!
We should make sure we are fully rejuvenated before we do anything else.
Hmm, I don't think that will work. Worth a try, though.
I have a good feeling about this. I don't think they're going to see us coming until it's too late.
I don't know, Kapitän. They're pretty tough. The worst part is how they've congregated now. They're going to be a force to reckon with.
Well, if this doesn't work, we'll find something that does. We're pretty good under pressure.
Whatever you plan on doing, I'll be by your side. After all, we're a team!
Thank you, Theodor. I mean it.
@BATTLE
Oh, I know! You don't say things you don't mean. It's one of the things that makes you you.
You... may be giving me too much credit.
Impossible.
Yeah?
... We should prepare for battle now!
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
I finally have a report for you, Kapitän. From reviewing our battles.
Excellent. What've you got?
At first glance, the Nixen seem to have been lapsing back into the erratic behavior they displayed at the start of the war - but it's more effective now. Casualty rates across the fleet are rising.
I'd heard that anecdotally. Are those the numbers?
Well, Kapitän, shall we retreat from the current theater, or shall we try a new strategy?

Fields.MenuText: Retreat isn't the word - but pulling back and drawing them after us has some appeal.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll inform the crew.
I'll draft up some new plans right away.
Well, I guess that could possibly work...
And we'll keep working on this. I'm not going to let them keep this momentum.
Ja.
... Damn.
Gut - freut mich zu hören.
Everything okay?
Always. I'm in good hands.
Flattering... and yet it feels vaguely evasive.
Ach es ist nichts. I'm just chewing on a... writing problem, Kapitän.
What's the current status of the Morganas?
Almost in Sichtweite. Squint for a few seconds and you may start to see them.
Good work.
We're going to need to push a little further. The Nixen are coming to an early stop.
What, just sit and wait for us? That's hardly their usual modus operandi.
Ja, I know. But that's what they plan to do.

Fields.MenuText: Do you also have a plan?

Fields.DialogueText: I've been up-to-date on their plans and schemes. It's what you assigned to me.
Nein. But I'm confident.
Our only plan should be to fight, and to win.
I hope this plan of yours works out well.
They won't expect us to charge forward... I hope.
... Okay. I trust you, Theodor.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Theodor, your predictions were 100% accurate.
Ja. I know they were. And I know exactly why.
Is this something I should know about?
Better sit down for this, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: If you tell me we've been getting secret assistance from animal companions...

Fields.DialogueText: ... Nein.
Nein, just... well... it's complicated for me.
Oh... well, okay. Suit yourself, then.
So. What's the news?
So, you recall how I lost my notebook? It went overboard. Well, I think the Nixen may have found it.
... I'm sorry. What?
These strange tactics that the Nixen are engaging in... It's all very similar to a story I wrote in that book.
So they're borrowing tactics from a fairy tale you wrote? And it's working?
I'm serious, though - it all came from my book. They must think that the book they found holds some of our battle strategies!
I'm impressed with you and disappointed in myself. In roughly equal measure.
Sorry. Fairy tale motifs, and... never mind.
I'm the servant who spilled the witch's poison on the horse. Or maybe I'm the witch.
Pardon?
You *do* realize this means I'm going to need you to be more involved in our tactical planning, right? Clearly you're amazing at it.
I'm a little bit amazing at writing stories about foxes who fall down wells and murderous bats! I don't know what kind of warped mind can turn those into battle plans, and-
*ahem*
Have *I* got a warped mind for you.
... You mean yours?
Oh, yes.
So, if anyone was harmed by the last few battles, I'm the one who's responsible.
Listen, so far, the only ones who have been harmed are the Morganas - their changes in tactics are tough, but we've countered them. Do you think they still have no idea that the book is fiction?
I think so.
I guess we'll have to form a plan, then.
I remember most of the story. It's all in my head. We could play out the story and let the Nixen fall right into our hands.

Fields.MenuText: Doing that may be our best option.

Fields.DialogueText: We're never going to be able to take out the Nixen by just flailing around.
I know it may lead us into danger, but there's a happy ending where we win... I think.
Thank you, Kapitän. I'll do what it takes in order to win.
So, Theodor, what's the next part of the story?
Well, the Nixen have held their position. So that means we'll find their friends just north from the last battle!
Okay. Let's go north!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
... Sometimes I really wonder about my life.
That's like saying the grandmother in Rotkäppchen is responsible for what the big, bad wolf does in her house.
Well, I mean, if she had better locks on her doors-
Really?
... Nein. My mouth just got away from my brain.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
So far, you've been right on the money. I can't believe an accidental disinformation campaign could be so effective.
So far so good, Kapitän. I'm doing my best to make sure that the Nixen won't be a nuisance!
So, you only had one story in this book, right? We don't have to worry about them switching from Hansel and Gretel to Snow White or... I know that look.
Um.

Fields.MenuText: Don't tell me you also wrote your diary in there.

Fields.DialogueText: It means I had a huge collection of anti-Nixen stories in there...
Some fantasy, some loosely based allegory on the war, and some romance, too.
Nein! No way! Das wäre ganz schrecklich!
So the Morganas are going to be extra-mad based on what's in the book, is that correct?
That's about right.
Okay.
It's just... I had a lot of little fantasies about Nixen coming to horrible ends in there.
... Now I really wish you'd let me read them.
Ja, ja. I know, we're at a tactical disadvantage because I wouldn't-
No, because I could use stories about Morganas coming to horrible ends every now and then.
And, just generally, because I like seeing how your mind works.
After fighting all these Nixen who are following my plans, I would have thought you'd had enough of how my mind works.
I actually can't tell you how much I hate that they've taken something you love and tainted it.
I should probably have said that before. You've handled this with real grace, but... well, I'm just sorry you've had to.
I know you are. Hey, do you know "Die Sterntaler?"
If you hum a few bars I can probably fake it.
Nein, nein. It's a story. An orphan girl gives away everything she owns until finally she's alone and naked in a field - and then a star rewards her with riches.
If you're comparing having your book stolen to giving away prized possessions... it doesn't seem like quite the same thing.
Let's just be clear, though: in this metaphor, I'm not the creepy, voyeuristic star throwing money at random under-dressed orphans, right?
Was?
I was thinking losing my book was more like the girl losing her family - the starting point rather than the main action. And what I'm shedding now are defenses I don't need. Perhaps?
... I don't know. It's a work in progress.
But you're all right?
Nicht wirklich. But I'm trying not to think about it too much.
Fair enough.
... I was trying to be funny.
Oh. I'm sure you'll figure it out eventually.
I just had no idea that anything dangerous could happen through writing these stories.
Nothing dangerous *should* have happened - it's a one-in-a-million chance. And it could be useful in the end.
You had the right word the other day. I was just having fun and now my stories are *tainted*.
They're not, though. The Morganas were always going be murderous lunatics - you didn't inspire that.
Have you ever caused your friends harm, even if it was by accident?
Then you know how it feels when you see all of the pain unfurl before your eyes.
You can't understand how I feel. It's as if I was helpless beneath the crushing power of the wake.
How can you not remember? Ugh, it's like an anvil on your conscience!
For what it's worth, I think the way to feel better about this is to work to resolve it. Being active cures a lot of ills.
Ja. You're right. That has worked for me so far, and I just... need to get back to it.
And I need your help. Where are the Morganas going? What happens next?
"You shall know that, only when I come back."
*sigh*
If it would help to let it out...
I know, but...
Pardon?
It's from "Der Teufel mit den drei goldenen Haaren." See, a king sends his son-in-law to Hell to get three hairs from the Devil, and-
Theodor. I love your enthusiasm, but...
Ja, ja - the point is that we have to keep going to where we're going, and trust that we'll find our opportunities along the way.
This isn't a story that ends with me naked in a field waiting for a star to make me rich, is it?
... That's an image that's going to be with me for a while.
How about we just forget I said anything?
I will make no such promise.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I think we have a problem.
What's wrong? We're doing a great job! You've really pulled through on this strategy and battle analysis.
Ja. Well... I don't really remember what happens next. In the story.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I can jog your memory.
Ah, hell. It was going so well for so long!

Fields.DialogueText: I sure hope so, Kapitän. We're going to be going in blind...
Without some of my Notizen, which were also in my book, I don't think you can help.
Well, let's not get too negative...
Just relax. It'll come back to you - you didn't write it that long ago. Just focus and-
I'm not the most focused individual in general, if you hadn't noticed.
It's part of my charm.
... Okay, I don't disagree.
You don't?
If you've got a mental block, sometimes relaxing is a better approach than obsessing over it.
They haven't thrown anything at us that we - that you - haven't been able to handle. I have no doubt that that'll continue to be the case whether or not you remember.
And, yes, it *is* part of your charm.
Danke.
Now go get back to work before I'm compelled to compliment you again.
Ha!
Kapitän!
Can it wait? It looks like we have company closing in.
That's what I've come to talk to you about. I remembered part of my story. I know what they're going to do!
And what's that?
Well, it's not very good, I'll give you that. They're coming from all sides.
I could have told you that.
I'm sorry it was a little late.

Fields.MenuText: Don't sweat it. It's not like you invented the tactic.
I said it before, and I'll say it again: we can handle whatever they've got.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke. I'll make sure we win, no matter what.
I'm sure we will! All we need to do is work together.
We're going to power through! Wir schaffen das schon!
Take control of the battle, Theodor. We have to make our stand.
If one of your stories offers any useful insights, now would be the time.
@BATTLE
If the opportunity presents itself, always befriend the Devil's grandmother.
... I'll file that away.
It looks like we're surrounded.
We need to stick close together in order to make it through the barrage of Nixen.
Right. I'm glad you're by my side. Is there a strategy from your book?
Just to be brief, we work together in order to break through the enemy lines, such as they are, and escape.
Then we follow the plot, er, I mean, we follow the plan until we get this all sorted out!
No problem at all. We've beaten many Nixen before... I just hope we can do it again.
A different strategy? Well, if you want. You're the Kapitän, so let's go!
I'm ready to take aim when you are.
I just have one thought. Why are they following the plans so closely? We've beaten them so far. Doesn't it seem futile?
Same. But, for now, we have to carry on.
Ja. You're right, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
I don't know. I've been a little bit worried that it's an elaborate trap - in theory, if they know what we expect them to do, they can string us along and surprise us at just the right time.
But I don't think they have the resources to deliver a surprise worse than this, so... your guess is as good as mine.
I think I've had enough guessing. I just want them to stop.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Ah. Some relief, for once.
*sniffle*
Theodor, you're crying.
It's just... my thoughts, my heart and soul went into that story. And it carries real meaning.
Of course. All of our ideas do.
But this story was just meant to be nothing. Just a silly little thing. But in the wrong hands, it has delivered nothing but problems. I never thought that I would made this war even worse.

Fields.MenuText: I know. None of this is what it ought to be.
You didn't. The war gets worse on its own.

Fields.DialogueText: I really never expected for any of it to be like this, Kapitän. It was all supposed to be for honor. Not for pain.
I don't like it. It's important, one's pride in one's country. But that doesn't make war any easier.
I can't blame it all on the Nixen. They're capable of learning, and *this* is what I've taught them.
Theodor... I think you need to realize that there is evil in this world. We can't only do good things.
Not even the words I write are completely pure. It has amounted to tremendous pain.
Wait, don't go away!
And I blathered on before about how losing my defenses would *help* me? I'm such a fool.
Theodor? Where are you?
I see you over there.
All right. I'm coming out.
*CRASH*
Ow... I tripped.
It's okay. I've got you. You all right?
Listen, I'm sorry, but I need your help now. There are Morganas close, and having you with me on the bridge makes a world of difference.
You... don't need to flatter me. I'm with you.
@BATTLE
I am. I'm sorry for overreacting.
... For the most part.
I didn't say your emotions *weren't* under control.
You didn't have to. I'm not ordinarily one of those Belles who storms out before a conversation is over, or who hides from her Kapitän... but look at me now.
But it's under control! No more weepy, silly Theodor! I promise!

Fields.MenuText: I don't actually have a problem with weepy, silly Theodor.
You're perfectly entitled to be unhappy here. It's a violation.
I admit, the timing isn't great.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I do.
You shouldn't. You have a deep sense of fairness, you feel things passionately - I mean, these are strengths. You remind me how valuable they are every day.
*sniff*
It's not about me. It's about my stupid hobby being used to hurt my crew.
Can you imagine what Deutschland would say? Or any of the *proper* Walküren?
That you should take it out on the Morganas.
Also, as your Kapitän, I officially instruct you not to call your hobby stupid. You're not to denigrate it any way, in fact, because it's essential to the good performance of this vessel.
And because I really want you to read me some new stories one day.
*deep breath*
I do have my emotions under control.
You know, even if a lot of bad things happen, I still realized a lot of good that has come out of fighting in the war.
That's really not what you were doing. But tell me about the good.
Well, for one, we make the world a safer place.
A world with less Morganas is a world I'd rather live in.
Ja. I agree. Besides, without the war I would still be asleep, I think. Being conscious has taught me a lot.
Well, I learned how to fight, and how to help make sure a ship stays in top shape at all times!
Oh... well, with these next few fights we can expect to fight together!
Das stimmt. And I'm sure we've all grown together. Look how strong we've become!
Well said, Theodor.
But, you know, I've been meaning to say I like how close we've become... It's just like... no, never mind.
Well, now I'm intrigued.
Um. Don't we have a battle to attend to?
You're right, we do.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Focusing on the positive? Very good.
Well, I needed an alternative to moping around like a child.
And, yeah, for my part, I can't even begin to say how glad I am that you're awake and active in the world.
If somebody told me I could end the war today, but it would put you back to sleep...
Honestly, I think I'm happier not thinking about it.
Well... um... in "Dornröschen," there's a special technique for waking someone in a magical sleep.
Yeah?
Not that it will come to that!
Do you remember what happens next in your story?
Ja. Sort of. I've got kind of a rough outline.
We'll have to make sure the Morganas don't change their strategy on us.
We've got to be up to the climax by now.

Fields.MenuText: Does that mean it'll get harder?
I wonder what we'll do next.

Fields.DialogueText: I usually don't make tense scenes... But you may be right, this will be a tough battle ahead of us.
When the Nixen come ahead of us, I'll make sure we stay around to win!
Well, like any good story, we'll get to the ending.
Stick close to me, Theodor. I'll make sure we get through this battle safely.
That's what I was hoping for, Kapitän.
When we're done, you can tell me what the official happy ending looks like.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Great! The world needs more words. A lot more words. Especially from someone so charming.
And I'm sure that's just the beginning.
I'm glad. Just... maybe chain the notebook to your wrist or something.

Fields.DialogueText: Awww - danke! I'm ready to be heard. I've grown to become more comfortable in my own skin, Kapitän.
I have a thousand new ideas, thanks to this little "Eskapade" of ours.
Ha ha. Very funny, Kapitän.
First things first, though. We're going to make our way through the Morganas. This is your last story's climax, right?
Ja, this is where we become Helden! One way or another.
Good. There shouldn't be many of them left to face!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Have you had any new ideas?
I'm not sure I understand, Kapitän. I thought our strategy was set. The Nixen are about to-
Story ideas. Sorry. I'm hoping you're about ready to start writing again.
Ah.
Not that it's any of my business, I suppose.
I like that you've made it your business, actually.
And I *do* plan to keep writing. I think I have the makings of a reworking of "Die Nixe im Teich" that could run for hundreds of pages.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Well, I think that's the last of them. We must be at the end of the story, don't you think?

Fields.MenuText: Not a bad result, if I say so myself.
I hope there's not a sequel.
That's how the story in your book ends?

Fields.DialogueText: I made sure to fight hard because I knew we could do it even though it meant hurting other living beings.
I'd rather just relax and have an end to this war, wouldn't you?
Well, there's some character development. I think I've got a proper denouement, all told.
Fair enough. All the story needs now is a catchy moral and we can move on to the next one.
You're about to say that the moral of the story is that I should be more careful about where I leave my things.
Well, there are *some* happy memories. I got to be by you!
Yeah?
Well... no, never mind. We'll discuss it later.
Wait! I want to discuss it now!

Fields.MenuText: I am not about to say that. Though you should.
I was *going* to say it, but now I'm just kind of at a loss.
Actually, I think the moral has something to do with not blindly following someone else's plans.

Fields.DialogueText: Danke.
Armer Kapitän!
Oh, das ist sehr gut! Ja, this is a very different story from the Nixen's point of view!
All that said... honestly, there's a part of me that's still sorry we couldn't get your book back.
It's fine. It wouldn't have happy memories associated with it if we did.
True.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
So, Theodor, this is how your "Die Nixe im Teich" variant ends? With a glorious sunset and a fiendish nixe or seven sinking to the seabed?
Ja, more or less. Is that satisfying to you?
Any ending should involve us defeating the Bösewichte, of course.
Well, then - maybe the story isn't over. Or the characters need to be driven a little more.
Yeah, it was the best I could do. I tried my best!
So, I've done some research, and I did notice one difference between your nixie of the mill-pond story and some of the other ones you've cited.
Well, what do you think?
It's just... I'm suddenly realizing that the Morganas have literally spent the last few weeks trying to kill us so I can't kiss you. And I thought I was furious with them before.
Ha!
So... can I give you some suggestions about the sequel?
Ja. But I think you should come much closer for it.
Ja?
The animal musicians, the naked orphan and the star - they didn't really have romantic elements, did they?
The prince got married at the end of "Das Rätsel."
The one with the poisoned horse and bird and bandits? Okay, granted - but I seem to recall that he married a woman who'd just spent three days trying to get his head cut off.
So there was some romantic tension. That can be healthy!
Tell me about it.
Now, I will admit, my version of "Die Nixe im Teich" has a heroic Kapitän being swept away by an evil Nixe and finally rescued by a silly girl who knows a thing or two about fairy tale logic.
This is the captain of a mill-pond.
Hush.
Sorry.
But... I was thinking it might end with a kiss. And then happily ever after.
I like it. It may be traditional, but I personally think it feels earned.
You haven't read the story yet.
Didn't we just live it?
I don't think the silly girl saved the Kapitän in the real world.
I think she does it so often she doesn't see it's happening.
And I think a good kiss could conceivably do wonders for the Captain's health right now.
... Would this be a bad time to mention that the story that went overboard also had a Kapitän and kissing?
What?
It's actually been a recurring theme in my work for a while.
